references: . It is well-known that increasing the number of local steps per round leads to greater drifts of the model from centralized learningÂ

.
However, using more local steps also updates the local models more, potentially leading to an improved average model. To balance these competing considerations, we discuss two criteria. For
, more local steps mean fewer communication rounds, in which
, understandably, using more local steps improves both
, since more local SGD updates are made in total.

, we conduct a finer-grained analysis of the opposite trend. Starting from the same initial model, we vary the number of local SGD steps per round but fix the total SGD steps. We show the test accuracy of the (aggregated) global model as the training proceeds (x-axis).
Comparing
, we see a drastically different effect of
. In particular, while the performance of
seems unreasonably robust to training with fewer communication rounds but more local steps per round, suggesting the need for a deeper analysis of
